0.0: [Mishnah]  ALL THE SUBSTITUTES FOR THE NAZIRITE VOW ARE EQUIVALENT TO NAZIRITE VOWS.
0.1: IF A MAN SAYS, ‘I SHALL BE [ONE].’ HE BECOMES A NAZIRITE. [IF HE SAYS.] ‘I SHALL BE COMELY, A NAZIRITE,
0.2: A NAZIK, A NAZIAH A PAZIAH. HE BECOMES A NAZIRITE.
0.3: [IF HE SAYS.] ‘I INTEND TO BE LIKE THIS,’ OR ‘I INTEND TO CURL [MY HAIR].’ OR ‘I MEAN TO TEND [MY HAIR].’ OR ‘I UNDERTAKE TO DEVELOP TRESSES,’ HE BECOMES A NAZIRITE.
0.4: [IF HE SAYS.] ‘I TAKE UPON MYSELF [AN OBLIGATION INVOLVING] BIRDS,’ R. MEIR SAYS
0.5: HE BECOMES A NAZIRITE, BUT THE SAGES SAY
0.6: HE DOES NOT BECOME A NAZIRITE.
0.7: [Gemarah]  Seeing that the Tanna is teaching the order Nashim, why does he speak of the nazirite? —
0.8: The Tanna had in mind the scriptural verse, Then it cometh to pass if she find no favour in his eyes, because he hath found some unseemly thing in her, and he reasons thus.
0.9: What was the cause of the woman's infidelity? Wine. Further, he proceeds,
0.10: whosoever sees an unfaithful wife in her degradation will take a nazirite's vow and abjure wine. [How is it that in enunciating the general rule, the Mishnah]
0.11: mentions first ‘substitutes’ and then gives examples of ‘allusions’?
0.13: There is a hiatus [in the Mishnah] and it should read as follows:
0.14: ‘All the substitutes for the nazirite vow are equivalent to nazirite vows, and all allusions to the nazirite vow are equivalent to nazirite vows.
0.16: If a man says.I shall be [one]." he becomes a nazirite [etc.].’
0.17: Ought not then the substitutes to be enumerated first
0.18: — It is customary for the Tanna to explain first what he mentions last.
0.20: With what materials may [the Sabbath lamp] be kindled, and with what may it not be kindled? and the exposition begins: It is forbidden to kindle etc. [Again, we learn:]
0.21: With what materials may [hot victuals] be covered [on the Sabbath,] and with what may they not be covered? and the exposition begins:
0.22: It is forbidden to cover etc. [Again:] What may a woman ‘wear when she goes out [on the Sabbath], and what may she not wear when she goes out? and the exposition begins: She must not go out etc.
0.24: With what trappings may an animal go out [on the Sabbath]. and with what may it not go out? whilst the exposition begins: The camel may go out etc.; [and again:]
0.25: Some both inherit and bequeath, and some inherit but do not bequeath. Some bequeath and do not inherit, and some neither inherit nor bequeath, whilst the exposition begins:
0.26: The following both inherit and bequeath? The truth is that the Tanna adopts sometimes one method and sometimes the other, [according to circumstances].
0.27: In the first set of cases adduced, because the prohibition is a personal one, this personal prohibition is expounded first.
0.28: On the other hand, in the case of the animal, since the prohibition arises primarily through the animal, those things which are permitted are mentioned first.

1.0: ...Rabbah the son of Bar Chana said that Rabbi Yochanan said:
1.1: That which it is written (Hosea 14:10) "for straight are the ways of Hashem and the righteous walk upon them and the sinners stumble upon them.
1.2: A parable to two people that roast their paschal lambs, one eats it for the purpose of the commandment and one eats it for the purpose of gluttony.
1.3: The one that eat it for the purpose of the commandment, "and the righteous walk upon them," the one that eats it for the purpose of gluttony, "and the sinners stumble upon them."
1.5: Is this one called an evildoer?
1.6: Although he has not performed the best form of the mitzvah, he still performed the paschal lamb.
1.7: Rather, it is parable to two people, this one has his wife and his sister with him and this one has his wife and his sister with him.
1.8: To this one his wife is set for him and to this one his sister is set for him, the one whose wife is set for him, "the righteous walk upon them," and the one whose sister is set for him, "and the sinners stumble upon them."
1.10: We were talking about one path, here are two paths.
1.11: Rather, it is a parable to Lot and his daughters that were with him.
1.12: They that intended for the sake of a commandment, "and the righteous walk upon them," he that intended for the sake of sin, "and sinners stumble upon them."
1.13: And maybe he too intended for sake of a commandment?
